From everyman to family man: The essence of Delaware's Joe Biden, our 46th US president

Joe Biden is ending more than five decades of political service with history-making bookends - he was the youngest ever elected to the U.S. Senate in modern times and is now the oldest to leave the country's highest office.

It's been a career fueled by ambition, resiliency, and idealism and highlighted by tragedy, disappointments and triumph. And while he is not leaving the office of the presidency the way he envisioned, Delaware - Biden's home for more than 70 years - has always been his touchstone. As vice president and president, he brought the world to his home state.

Biden told The News Journal in 1976 that he was not sure if he ever wanted to live in the White House.

True to his word, he has returned to Delaware so often during his one-term presidency that locals have dubbed the traffic backups created by his motorcade as "Joe Jams."

And Biden's encounters with the locals are uniquely Delaware.

"It's like Elvis in Memphis. Everyone has a Biden story if they've lived here long enough," said Jude Baseden, who resides in north Wilmington.

Wilmington's Bill Pegram had his Biden moment in 2019 when he spotted the then-former vice president leaving a Greenville coffee shop with a cup of joe, stopping his truck in the middle of the parking lot to shake his hand.When Biden learned Pegram's father, Richard, was a World War II veteran, he told Pegram to get his then-95-year-old father on the phone.

"He thanked him for his service and made my father's day," Pegram recalled. "Politics aside, anyone who would call my dad and thank him like that - I have to give a little appreciation to him."

Biden always told the press and anyone who listened that he wanted to be known as "just plain Joe."

A former assistant public defender, Biden was a criminal lawyer with the Wilmington law firm of Aerenson and Balick in 1971 when he decided as a New Castle County councilman to run for the U.S. Senate seat against incumbent Sen. J. Caleb Boggs.

Biden was a county councilman for only 16 months. At the time, News Journal columnist Al Cartwright said Boggs, who had been elected statewide to public office since 1946 - three times as a U.S. representative, twice as governor, and twice as U.S. senator - had shoes older than Biden.

The 29-year-old Biden's youth and stunning upset over a veteran lawmaker who seemed unbeatable propelled him into the spotlight as a national political figure where he would remain for 52 years.

The senator "ran as Joe Biden and was elected as Joe Biden and he signs his name Joe Biden," said Wes Barthelmes, Biden's administrative assistant, who had once worked for the late Sen. Robert F. Kennedy, in February 1973.

"Don't keep looking for mystique. There's no mystique. He's just just a hard-working senator," Barthelmes would later say.

The "just Joe" theme would be repeated at a March 1973 chicken-and-covered dish dinner for Sussex County Democrats in Wesley United Methodist Church hall.

Biden became emotional and wept as he stood on the same stage where he first announced his candidacy for U.S. Senate to Sussex County voters a year earlier. The last time he was there, Biden was with his wife, Neilia, who had died three months earlier in an automobile accident.

"I very seldom have trouble speaking, as you know, but this is where we started," he said as his voice trembled.

Several in the audience cried openly as Biden said, "My wife had a great deal of respect for you all. I didn't want to come tonight. ... I've never done this [cry] in public ...." Biden regained his composure, continued the speech, and told the audience he was still "Joe Biden, not Senator Biden."

He received a standing ovation and perhaps for the first time realized he could find solace and strength in shared grief.

Biden's ability to work a rope line, pump up a crowd, or connect with a random voter on the street has always been among his superpowers.

He may live in million-dollar houses in Greenville and Rehoboth Beach that many will never be able to afford, but he still can come across as someone most can relate to on a middle-class level.

As one News Journal article noted in 1986, "He is a man who lives in a mansion on the edge of Chateau Country, but who treats his family to pizza after a long day in Washington and takes guests out to lunch at a sub shop." He's also the kind of guy who is genuinely wowed when his staff flies in Charcoal Pit milkshakes as a surprise treat following his Democratic National Convention speech last year.

But when it comes to voters, he looks them square with his blue eyes undistracted, trained on its target. The 6-foot former University of Delaware football player asks how you are and about your family, sometimes with both hands on your shoulders.

There's always a handshake or two. Or three. And then there's The Smile. For his entire career, he has turned on the huge grin, revealing gleaming perfect rows of white teeth, whether he's happy with a question just asked - or looking to duck one.

When a 35-year-old Biden broke his right wrist sliding head-first into third base at a 1978 charity baseball game in Claymont, it left him in a cast up to his elbow for six weeks.

For a gregarious senator, losing his ability to use his hand-shaking arm was akin to Samson getting a buzzcut. Not to mention how it hindered his speech-giving, which sometimes seemed to be powered by arm movement. At the time, Biden conceded the broken wrist may leave him speechless.

But, of course, it did not. His ability to talk. And talk. And talk some more quickly became legendary when he landed in the U.S. Senate office he held continuously for Delaware from 1973 to 2009.

As he said at the Sussex County Democrats' Jamboree in 1988 during his heavily-anticipated return to the public eye following his brain aneurysm: "I do miss this." As 1,000 cheered the start of his comeback, he added, "It's the honest-to-God's truth. I could hardly wait to get here."

When it comes to Biden's gift for gab, many have noticed during his presidency what Delawareans have known for decades: He will often tell the same stories or use the same phrases repeatedly.

One News Journal columnist in 1982 mentioned that Biden opened a recent speech by "dragging out the Gumboro gas station joke that it seems he has been using since the Nixon administration."

News Journal columnist Norm Lockman wrote in 1973 that Biden sometimes "indulged in a little self-pity that makes some people wonder about his own sincerity." Shortly after his wife Neilia's 1972 death, he had talked about her so frequently in speeches that people began criticizing him, particularly in Delaware (and mostly behind his back) for exploiting the tragedy, Lockman wrote.

"There are people who think I've taken advantage of the tragedy. It makes me mad, but it's understandable. I know it looks contradictory. Why should this guy who wouldn't let anyone come to her funeral turn around and, in a political context, talk about his wife and a personal relationship?" Biden said.

"But I can't help it. I can try not to talk about it, but if it comes up, then I can't talk about Neilia without talking about Neilia. I can't help but become personal. I mean, I just can't treat her memory like some campaign worker who is gone and it's all over with."

In recent years, Biden has often mentioned his late son Beau in speeches and sometimes receives the same criticism.

Still, his folksy homespun tales, paired with jokes and knowledge of foreign and domestic issues, were a potent combination when combined with his natural charisma and ability to connect one on one with voters.

That everyman persona would sometimes create headlines on its own, like in 1977 when two teens snatched a purse from a 41-year-old woman in Wilmington.

On his 35th birthday, Biden was nearby and heard her scream while driving home on Miller Road after dropping his children off at the movies. He raced down 27th Street, hopped out of his car, and chased the pair, dubbed "quick little devils" by the woman - jumping a pair of fences in the process. One of them eventually dropped the purse as the senator gained on them.

"I was really disappointed I didn't get [the thieves], but at least I got her purse," he told a reporter at the time.

In March 1969, Biden - then a lawyer living off Marsh Road - found and helped an injured St. Bernard in front of his office at the Farmers Bank Building. The 80-pound dog was limping from an injury to its right paw. Biden took off his belt and put it around the dog's neck as a makeshift leash.

He put the dog in his car and drove it to his home, even though he was late for court. Biden said he was a sucker for stray animals. The dog joined two cats named Foupi and Squirrel and a German shepherd named Senator at his home until the owner was found and the dog was returned to its home.

Biden's dogs would gain even more headlines over the years.

Jude Baseden, who referenced Elvis in Memphis when describing Biden in Delaware, and two friends found Biden's lost Great Dane in 1975 when she was 12 years old in the Brandywood neighborhood in Talleyville.

She and her friends thought they would be rewarded for finding the dog known as "Governor." Every day, Baseden went to the mailbox looking for a letter and a reward. A few weeks later, a large brown envelope came. Inside was a thank you letter from Biden.

He included a black-and-white glossy photo of himself. Baseden, then known as Judy, said there was no money and no reward.

"I was really mad and tore up the photo," now says Baseden, adding that people need to remember she was 12 at the time.

History took some time to sink in and Baseden said she now appreciates the letter. It hangs in a frame on the wall in her Wilmington-area home.

Biden's German shepherds Champ, Major and Commander lived in the White House. The elderly Champ, a good boy who also lived at the vice president's Number One Observatory Circle , died in 2021. But Major and Commander were banished from Washington for good after multiple biting incidents. The president's cat, Willow, remains.

Joe Biden's mouth has always been both an asset and a liability.

News Journal columnist Lockman said Biden "has the shortest link between his brain and his mouth of any big-time Delaware politician."

Biden in October 1973 spoke in Chicago shortly after then-President Nixon appeared on TV in a press conference and said Nixon had done for politicians "about what the Boston Strangler did for door-to-door salesmen."

Back in Delaware, Biden said he received a telegram about his comments and he read the contents: "I resent the comparison. [signed] The Boston Strangler."

The younger Biden could especially be a big mouth with enough bluster to fill a few Senate offices, an impression made immediately when he complained about the size of his Senate salary as a freshman lawmaker.

"I do not know about others, but I'm worth a lot more than my salary of $42,500 a year in this body," the 30-year-old said in July 1973. "I'd better shut up or I'm going to lose the next election before I get a chance to run."

Biden later said he regretted "shooting off at the mouth."

He once called a former colleague a "phony SOB" in 1994 - Democratic Colorado Sen. Tim Wirth, for the record - and in 2022 he called Fox News's Steve Doocy a "stupid son of a bitch" while speaking to himself in a hot mic moment as reporters were leaving a press conference.

Biden has changed over the years, however. He's softer-spoken and the loss of son Beau, whose promising political career seemed posed to track with his father's, has left a sad void.

After the disastrous debate with former President Donald Trump in June sparked a widespread push for him to end his candidacy, the fire-breather seemed like he would struggle to blow out a birthday candle. While he still can show a flash of his old self, he has slowed down markedly.

He has also evolved on some issues.

For example, he voted for a 1994 bill co-sponsored by North Carolina Republican Sen. Jesse Helms to cut off federal funding to any school district that has programs "encouraging or supporting homosexuality as a positive lifestyle alternative." But 18 years later, he would famously get out in front of President Obama and voice his support for same-sex marriage on NBC's "Meet the Press" in a headline-making moment.

On other issues, he has not changed his stance. Biden grew up Catholic and still regularly attends Mass at St. Joseph on the Brandywine in Greenville and St. Edmond's in Rehoboth Beach, but believes in a woman's right to choose abortion.

Biden's attachment to his family goes beyond the often-told tragedy of the 1972 Hockessin car accident that stole his wife Neilia and 13-month-old daughter, Naomi Christina, known as "Amy." Or the 2015 cancer death of his son Beau. Or his famous weekday commutes every morning and night to Washington via Amtrak as a senator.

The Biden clan has always kept its circle tight. Joe's parents, two brothers, sister, and brother-in-law all worked on his first Senate campaign. "We have very few close friends outside of the family," said his wife, Neilia, a week before her death.

Biden's beloved mother, Catherine "Jean" Biden, frequently told her children: "Family is the beginning, the middle, and the end. Period."

His younger sister, Valerie Biden Owens, has played a central role in her brother's life as an advocate, strategist and best friend. She is a frequent companion to Biden at the 5 p.m. Saturday church service at St. Joseph on the Brandywine, and the pair also sometimes meet up for meals around Wilmington at old familiar places like Mrs. Robino's in Little Italy.

Owens had been her brother's campaign manager for more than five decades beginning with a high school race. She became the first woman in United States history to run a presidential campaign. In 1987, Owens was by Biden's side when he ended his first run for president after being accused of plagiarizing a speech from United Kingdom Labour Party leader Neil Kinnock.

Wife Jill Jacobs, whom he married in 1977, has been his rock. He is so proud of his wife and her long career as an educator that he often says in speeches, "I'm Jill Biden's husband."

The affection between the couple is longstanding. Joe and Jill were known to sprawl out on facing seats on the Amtrak train home from Washington when he was a senator. She would kick off her shoes and put her feet in his lap.

On his last day as vice president in 2017, Joe and Jill Biden rode an Amtrak train home to Wilmington. The next day, he showed up at an indoor track meet at Tower Hill School to watch his grandchildren.

His daughter Ashley could often be seen by his side during overseas trips as vice president and president.

And his sons were an especially ubiquitous presence as they grew from high schoolers into college students, more able to take part in their father's fast-moving world.

That was then-20-year-old Georgetown University student Hunter Biden in 1990 attending each day of the contentious Senate Judiciary Committee hearings for the nomination of Supreme Court Justice Clarence Thomas.

Nearly 35 years later, one of the most controversial moments of Biden's presidency would be granting sweeping amnesty to Hunter - convicted of federal gun charges and also pleading guilty to federal charges of tax evasion - after promising not to pardon him. The move might have shocked the nation, but many Delawareans, long familiar with the Biden family's closeness, were hardly surprised.

When then-22-year-old Beau Biden was graduating from the University of Pennsylvania in 1991, his father was there to give the commencement address. Closing his speech, which had been void of any mention of the special family connection to the day, Biden simply stated, "Congratulations Beau," from behind the podium.

Biden decided against delving into their relationship because it would be "cheating the other parents on this special day," he told the press, before adding that he was also worried he'd embarrass Beau by "losing it. I'm afraid if I had tried that at all, I wouldn't have been very good at it. We've come a long way together."

Instead, he shared a quick hug and kiss with his son when Beau collected his diploma on stage before the procession continued.

After a high-risk surgery for a life-threatening brain aneurysm in February 1988 and suffering from a serious pulmonary embolism complication, Biden stayed out of the public eye as he recovered.

His first public appearance came two months later when he sneaked into Archmere Academy's mock presidential debate to support 18-year-old Hunter's performance as the Rev. Jesse Jackson from a production booth. He was unseen by parents and participants that night. His own staff didn't know about the outing until they read about it in the newspaper.

His closeness to Delaware and his family could also be used as a political weapon.

During his 1990 campaign against former Delaware Attorney General and Superior Court Judge M. Jane Brady, she accused Biden of being part of bureaucratic Congress and "out of touch" with the state at a voter forum.

But Biden earned applause from the 300-person crowd - many of whom were wearing "Joe" campaign stickers on their chest - when he countered by asking how he could be out of touch if he took the train home from Washington every night, lives in Delaware, shops in Delaware and sends his children to school in Delaware.

His medical setbacks in early 1988, less than five months after dropping out of his first presidential run amid the plagiarism charges, had the effect of calming the hard-charging Biden, leaving him more subdued and philosophical, even serene, as he described himself at the time.

After recovery, he told the Washington Post he understood how he could have come off as a "hothead." At the very start of his Senate career, he once rattled off terms used to describe himself, some of which came from his political enemies: "brash," "glamor boy," glib-tongued" and "arrogant" were some of them.

Sometimes, those characterizations came to life in front of television cameras.

Just days before he dropped out, Biden squared off with a voter questioning his aptitude.

The voter quizzed him about his law school career and Biden shot back, "I think I probably have a much higher IQ than you do, I suspect," before adding, "I'd be delighted to sit down and compare my IQ to yours if you'd like," and rattling off a steady stream of his academic accomplishments.

The voter responded by saying, "I'm not questioning your IQ. I'm just saying that with the people that we have elected to office in recent years, I think that we have to question their credentials very solidly."

More than four years earlier, a voter was on the receiving end of a testy exchange with Biden in front of visiting PBS cameras, this time at a town meeting on the home turf of his alma mater Archmere Academy.

Biden was questioned about calling fighting forces in El Salvador "rightists and leftists."

"Since you're so damn well informed, let me answer your question," Biden spat at his critic. The voter fought back: "What do you mean I'm so damn well informed? You guys like it when someone isn't informed. Look, I pay your salary senator ...."

For every angry confrontation, there are thousands of moments where Biden used his equally natural charm on voters.

When Biden is out living his life in Delaware, he is a selfie magnet. He seems to stop for anyone, anywhere. That's why many Delawareans seem to have a selfie with Biden somewhere, whether it's in a photo folder on Facebook or framed in their home.

His genial, outgoing nature is on display during local coffee runs, but also when it matters most.

Seaford-born 21-year-old U.S. Marine Michael A. "Moke" Hastings was killed in a bombing in Beirut, Lebanon, that killed 240 other U.S. military personnel 35 years ago when Biden was a senator.

In a News Journal letter to the editor published more than a year after the bombing, the Hastings family wrote about the help Biden and his staff gave in the aftermath of his death. They noted other politicians had called and offered long-term help, but never left a phone number. Biden left several to make sure they could always reach him.

"Sen. Biden took the time to come to Seaford for our son's funeral, but it didn't stop there," they wrote. "He has called several times since to ask how we were doing. A friend in need is a friend, indeed, and we'll never forget his acts of kindness."

Biden's ability to help others during times of grief can be traced back to 1972 when about 650 people attended the December memorial service at St. Mary Magdalen Catholic Church off Concord Pike in Talleyville for his wife Neilia and daughter Naomi. Biden showed up unexpectedly and comforted mourners.

More than 40 years later, he again would do the same for the thousands who waited hours in a more than two-block-long procession at Wilmington's St. Anthony of Padua Catholic Church to pay their respects to Neilia and Joe's oldest son, Beau Biden, who died of cancer in 2015 at age 46.

The plagiarism kerfuffle during his first presidential campaign in 1987 left Biden somewhat abashed after he dropped out of the race.

"It's a humbling experience," he said several months later. "But I deserve to be humbled. ... I made serious mistakes and I made stupid mistakes."

It also opened the floodgates to national ridicule for Biden. And local opponents thought it would stick, finally giving them an angle at taking down the swaggering wunderkind. It never did.

At the time, his 1984 senate challenger John Burris said, "His magic, his invisible shield has been pulled away ... that almost invisible bubble has been popped. [The credibility question] didn't stick in 1984. Next time around it will."

Even in hindsight, you can't fault them for believing the future U.S. president could have been mortally wounded politically. He was a walking, talking punchline - pantsed on the national stage.

Late-night talk show hosts fed off on the scandal, as they continued to do after he ascended to the vice presidency and presidency, more focused on his uncanny ability to talk his way into gaffes.

On "The Tonight Show," Johnny Carson joked, "Joe Biden called his staff together and said the whole plagiarism issue is nothing to worry about. There's nothing to fear, but fear itself, he said."

David Letterman also chimed in on "Late Night," joking that Biden's new campaign slogan was "Kennedy '68."

Even two years later, a 1990 episode of the family sitcom "Growing Pains" starring Alan Thicke and Kirk Cameron took a jab. A character sold his sister's term papers to fellow students at school. When the principal found out, he told their parents and before reading one of the copied papers, he said, "And just listen to this one that Joey Biden turned in!"

Newsweek even used his name as a synonym for plagiarism - "committing a Biden."

As someone as prideful as Biden - "I give you my word as a Biden," as he often says - seeing his name mutate into a cause for mockery in front of the world must have been jarring; a real shot to his healthily-sized ego. But for a man sometimes known for his braggadocio, he didn't let it show for long.

When reporters asked if he was politically hurt, Biden responded, "My feeling is not at all," before launching into one of his famous anecdotes.

He recalled entering the men's room of an Italian restaurant a month after his campaign ended in disaster and was met with a standing ovation when he left.

"You can't be a major leader without taking some very hard knocks," he declared.

One of the hardest for President Biden came during a late July weekend this past summer at his Rehoboth Beach home as he grappled with the idea that polls, donors, and voters had lost confidence in the nominee and felt that at age 81, Biden was too old to win a second term.

On July 20, Judge Jane Roth, the wife of Biden's longtime Delaware colleague, the late Sen. Bill Roth, shared with Delaware Online/The News Journal that Biden's situation seemed to mirror her husband's heart-breaking reelection loss in 2000 to Tom Carper.

"I have witnessed the grief of a politician, one with a long record of significant accomplishments when he loses the support of the people," Judge Roth wrote in an opinion piece. "Bill thought he would win despite his age and his health problems. The reality was that the voters wanted a younger representative with new ideas and new energy. For Bill, it was a very sad ending to his 30 years in the Senate. I think he never got over it. As his spouse, I believe he would have been happier if he had bowed out. His remaining years would not have been touched with a sense of loss but instead with one of accomplishment."

One day later, on July 21, Biden once again made political history when he decided to bow out of the race.

How Biden will be remembered remains to be seen.

In the closing days of his administration last month, he spoke of his legacy at a holiday reception at the White House in broad strokes.

"The one thing I always believed about public service, especially about the presidency, is the importance of asking yourself, 'Have we left the country in better shape than we found it?'" he said. "Today I can say with every fiber of my being and all my heart that the answer to that question is a resounding yes."

That reflective moment came more than 51 years after he spoke about legacy at a Hotel du Pont dinner honoring the man Biden had just beat for the senate seat: his two-term Republican predecessor and former Delaware Gov. J. Caleb Boggs.

In the speech, a young Biden laid out what he hoped for himself when his time as a public servant came to an end, without knowing it would be five decades later when he walked out of the White House for the last time as our nation's 46th president.

"I hope I will live to have what Cale Boggs has today: an unblemished reputation for integrity."

Letters to Joe: Messages, words of wisdom and thanks as Biden leaves the White House

As Joe Biden exits the White House, we asked those who know him, have worked with him and even a few folks who are also in the national spotlight and from Delaware, to share their memories, well-wishes and send-off messages to the outgoing president.

Here's what they had to say.

I met Joe Biden when I was sixteen years old at the Joe Biden youth leadership conference in Delaware. I was so excited to be chosen to represent my high school and get to voice my opinions about local issues and policies. I'll never forget Joe delivering the closing speech in the auditorium - his face getting all red because he was so impassioned. I can't remember the topic of the speech, but I knew he meant every word he was saying up there! It was fiery and we all loved it.

Years later, when I was cast on "Parks and Recreation," I had the privilege of working with Joe and Jill. We got a tour of the vice president's office and I found a note on Joe's desk that had my name on it and some facts about where we had met in Delaware. I felt so special that he remembered we had a history. In true April Ludgate style, I pocketed the note. Mike Schur [the creator of "Parks and Recreation"] was very concerned I'd get in trouble. It was the White House after all. You can't steal from the White House! Turns out you can.

Some more years later, I was asked to host "Saturday Night Live." A dream come true. I pitched an idea to Lorne Michaels to have Joe (who was the sitting president at that time) do a little bit in my monologue. Lorne seemed skeptical, but he let me pursue it. I was hoping that Joe would remember me enough to want to participate. But I wasn't sure I could pull it off. Not only did he say yes -- he left a heartwarming voicemail on my phone after he filmed his bit.

He said on the message, "Hey kid, it's Ashley Bidens dad...," and it made me laugh. Even as the sitting president, he was still the same guy. A total sweetheart.

Aubrey Plaza is an actor, comedian and Ursuline Academy graduate.

I am not a very political person, but I can certainly recognize the importance of hard work and bringing pride to the country you represent.

I want to thank President Biden and Dr. Biden for their contributions to our country, to our futures and for keeping us safe.

As a Delawarean, I hope that President Biden's legacy will be a message to all young people that even if you're from a little state, you can dream big.

Johnny Weir is a retired figure skater and American commentator who calls Delaware home.

Mr. President,

Like virtually every Delawarean, we could tell too many stories about your impact on our lives. Jobs that represented transformative beginnings; celebrations of births and support after deaths; conversations about the meaning of service and citizenship, about family, friendship... and football.

Throughout those personal stories, there are themes that, to us, have also defined your public leadership.

Starting in 1972, always with respect for those who came before, you gave us faith that our then-young voices mattered - to you and to the country. We felt that message on a personal level, at the same time recognizing that it was for all who had not been heard or seen enough in the halls of power. And you said, and showed, that honoring the dignity of each of us could strengthen the community of all of us.

You've called on us, at every phase, "to remember who we are," toward upholding both our individual integrity and our shared identity as Americans. You've embodied the confidence that our ideals are not just about a world that should be; they are also essential to getting things done in the world that is. What we say we value - as you defined it, "opportunity, liberty, dignity, respect, honor, service, and truth" - are not just ideas; they must be action items, in the world of policy and in how we treat one another.

As one of the writers you quote most - "not because they are Irish but because they are the best" - Seamus Heaney once said of poetry, you have touched "the base of our sympathetic nature while taking in at the same time the unsympathetic nature of the world." You've lived that paired reality of courage and vulnerability, often to our amazement, finding in too much heartbreak a renewed inspiration to serve.

So your leadership, like your friendship, is chronicled not only in what has been done - remarkable in itself - but also in what has been felt, an honesty of the heart that your neighbors and fellow Americans could always trust. Like the care and compassion of your personal connections, the public faith you've preached - "possibility" - has been more persuasive, and more practiced, because of that trust. True to the lesson of your Finnegan grandparents, you haven't just kept the faith, you've spread it.

You've often said that "Delaware" is written on your heart. As we welcome you and Jill back to where your heart is most at home, we wish for you and your family what you've always wished for all of us, that, "He will raise you up on eagles' wings/Bear you on the breath of dawn/Make you to shine like the sun/And hold you in the palm of His hand."

John Carney is the mayor of Wilmington and, most recently, former governor of Delaware. Former first spouse Tracey Quillen Carney worked on the staff of then-Sen. Joe Biden for 15 years.

Dear Joe,

Fifty-three years ago, my brother, Robbie Richards, invited my husband Bill and me to come to dinner to meet a young New Castle County Councilman who Robbie thought had a bright future. Bill and I were a little surprised because the young man was a Democrat, and we were all Republicans. But we went to dinner and met you, Joe, and your first wife, Neilia. The dinner was a success. The conversation was lively and we were impressed by both you and Neilia. Bill and I agreed that you would go far.

We were somewhat taken aback a year later when you ran for the other Senate seat against our good friend, the incumbent, Cale Boggs. In an upset. you beat Cale but Bill understood the reality of politics. Bill was sorry that Cale had lost but he was glad that he already knew his new colleague.

Then Neilia and your daughter Naomi were tragically killed in an automobile accident. Your two sons, Beau and Hunter, were seriously injured. You were distraught. It was difficult for you to think of the future without Neilia and Naomi. Your family and friends, however, encouraged you to move forward with your Senate career. You decided that you would be sworn in as Senator in the hospital room where your sons were recovering. Bill and I attended this hospital room swearing-in. Your two little boys had an unparalleled view of this important step in their father's life. On this occasion, I witnessed your deep devotion to your family.

Thus began 28 years of Bill and you working together in the U.S. Senate to represent Delaware. To be with your family, you returned by train to Wilmington every evening and took the train back to Washington in the morning. Bill also often came back in the evening and returned the next day. You frequently took the same train. When you did, you often sat together. Both of you worked hard on the train, reading and writing. And, If you were sitting together and busy working, constituents would be less likely to interrupt you by stopping and chatting. You got a lot done by sitting together.

Over the years, you and Bill, a Democrat and a Republican, learned what areas you both would support and where you did not agree on policy. With this understanding, you were very effective in representing the people of Delaware. When you could work together, you got a lot done. I also benefited personally from your being a Senator. When I was nominated to the U.S. District Court in 1985 and to the Third Circuit Court of Appeals in 1991, Bill, as my spouse, couldn't very well present me to the Judiciary Committee for its approval. You stepped in and did so - and very enthusiastically. It meant a lot to me to have that bipartisan support.

Bill died in 2003 and then my daughter Katy died in 2014 after an extended illness. On both occasions, you gave me great support in my grief. At Katy's memorial service, you told me about the illness of your son, Beau. This was before there was public awareness of the gravity of Beau's condition. I could tell how stricken you were by Beau's illness. But you were also thinking of my situation. You could appreciate my grief while experiencing your own.

I had strong Republican roots before becoming a judge, but as a constituent I have observed your dedication to your job and to the people you represent. I admire you for the many things you have done both for the State of Delaware and for the country. It's been wonderful to have had a President from Delaware - one who spoke as a statesman with world leaders, who funded infrastructure improvements throughout our country, and who was at the same time a consummate politician - indeed, here was a bright young man who went far. And I am very proud of our First Lady, Jill. She has been a superb wife for you.

But when I think of you, Joe. I think not of the Senator or Vice President or President. I think of the friend who is dedicated to his family and who understands grief -- not just his own, but mine as well. You have relieved my grief. You know grief's enduring nature but you have learned to live with it in order to maintain a life of service to others. This life of service is what you will be remembered for and why we are proud of you.

Joe, that is what you mean to me.

Best wishes to you, Jane Roth

Jane R. Roth is a senior judge for the U.S. Court of Appeals for the 3rd Circuit and wife of the late Bill Roth, a long-serving U.S. senator from Delaware. She currently resides in Washington, D.C.

I was first introduced to Joe Biden when I was serving in the United States Navy. During one of my six-month deployments in Southeast Asia, the best days were when the mail came, bringing cards, care packages, newspapers, and magazines. After learning of my military service in Southeast Asia, he embraced me and welcomed me to Delaware, marking the beginning of a friendship that has lasted for 50 years.

Joe Biden has a saying that "all politics are personal." During the last five decades, those words have served both of us well. Making personal connections with people in Delaware - and around the world - has allowed him to attain the highest level of office, but still remember he is a public servant at the end of the day. Some people may think that Joe Biden is just a partisan and only likes to work with Democrats, but he can work with just about anyone. Early in his Senate career, he did that with people like Senator John Stennis (D-Miss.) and even Senator Strom Thurmond (R-S.C.). One might ask, how could a Democrat ever find common cause with any of those guys? But Joe Biden did, and he's been able to do the same thing in the years since then including his time as President.

It's his bipartisan approach that has largely paved the way for our country to make historic economic progress during his presidency. Over 16 million jobs have been created over the last four years, and in 2023 alone, a total of 2.7 million jobs were created, which is more jobs that any single year under the previous administration. That's more than the populations of Delaware, Kansas, Nebraska, New Mexico, Oklahoma, and West Virginia combined! The improvement in inflation over the last year is the best story never told, with inflation now below 3 percent, the lowest level since April 2021.

American manufacturing is roaring back. The United States has made the most substantial investments in science, innovation, and industrial strategy in over 50 years, and more than 700,000 manufacturing jobs have been added across the country. Thanks to the historic investments in two landmark bills that I helped to author at the encouragement of Joe Biden who signed them into law - the Bipartisan Infrastructure Law and the Inflation Reduction Act - we have made a commitment to build a new clean energy economy which is creating good-paying jobs while helping to save our planet. Joe Biden is a man of his word and a person of unfailing integrity, and it is that commitment to doing what is right - not what is easy - that has earned him the respect of voters and world leaders alike. When challenged in his personal or professional life, he puts his country ahead of himself. He has proven that people can disagree without being disagreeable, and that we can compromise on policy without compromising our principles.

For over five decades, Joe Biden has been a principled leader and an even better friend. More importantly, though, he is a devoted husband, a loving father and grandfather, and a dedicated son and brother. It is those qualities that have helped make him an exceptional person and an excellent president.

Tom Carper is a former U.S. senator who represented Delaware for years.

You can't tell the story of modern Delaware politics without Joe Biden, but it's also true that you can't tell the story of Joe Biden without Delaware. Sure, Joe is understandably proud of his Scranton, Pennsylvania roots, but it's what he learned in Delaware that most shaped his approach to public service.

As I came up in Delaware politics, I often heard people speak of the "Delaware Way." While it can mean different things to different people, the general idea is that folks work together to overcome their differences and find common ground. Joe took that Delaware Way to Washington, and that's an important part of what's made him so successful as a senator and vice president, and the most consequential president of my lifetime.

When he made a focus on bipartisanship and working together a central theme of his primary campaign in 2020, Joe was at times dismissed as naively believing in a bygone era. Once Joe won, he began proving the naysayers wrong, building bipartisan majorities in Congress to pass transformative legislation to invest in America's infrastructure, re-shore advanced manufacturing, fulfill our sacred obligation to veterans, protect communities from gun violence, and invest in community mental health.

He did all that by bringing people together, not by tearing us apart. He led on the national stage by staying true to his Delaware roots.

It's not just Delaware's political civility that shaped Joe, however. No matter where he goes, he is always Joe from Claymont, son of a hardworking car salesman who valued the dignity of work as much as a paycheck. Coupled with his mother's "American creed" - that "no one is better than you. You are everyone's equal, and everyone is equal to you" - Joe has never stopped believing in the remarkable possibilities that America offers and the importance of treating people with respect.

It's a promise grounded in the values strengthened by the nuns at St. Helena's and Holy Rosary, who stressed the importance of "decency, fair play, and virtue." Joe's early parochial education, followed by his four years at Archmere, bolstered his Catholic faith and a belief in the obligations we all have to each other. The nuns taught their students that "it was noble to intervene," as Joe recalled in his memoir, emphasizing above all the broader lesson of John 15:13: "No one has greater love than this, to lay down one's life for one's friends."

You can draw a direct line from Joe's Catholic education to his decision to take a lifeguarding job at a majority Black swimming pool in Wilmington as a 19-year-old during the Civil Rights Movement. Joe knew very little about the Black experience in Delaware, a segregated state at the time, but he was determined to change that by listening to his peers at Prices Run public swimming pool. There, Joe met lifelong friends like Richard "Mouse" Smith and Maurice Pritchett, who - between swimming laps and playing late-night basketball games - explained the challenges they faced as young Black men in 1960s America. Joe took his new friends' messages seriously. As Pritchett recounted, "Biden, you could see it in his eyes, he wanted to know about us." Pritchett and Smith described the repeated indignities - what Joe later termed the "dozen small cuts a day" - that left them hurt and angry.

Those stories resonated with Joe. After all, one of Joe's defining values is that he hates bullies; hates it when people misuse power and refuse to give others a fair shake. It's what's driven him to do more to counter racial inequality than any president in 50 years: funding HBCUs at record levels; appointing an historically diverse slate of federal judges to the bench, including Supreme Court Justice Ketanji Brown Jackson, the first Black woman on our nation's highest court; and creating economic opportunity for Black Americans by emphasizing underserved communities and Black homeownership, among many other priorities.

This is the man who served as the loyal No. 2 to our nation's first Black president, Barack Obama, and who chose Kamala Harris as his running mate in 2020, leading her to become the first Black vice president (and then solidly endorsed Harris for president after ending his own campaign this summer). Once confronted with the inequality and indignities imposed on Delawareans by decades of racial segregation, the values of his faith and his family made Joe a lifelong advocate for racial equality.

Once again, it all comes back to Delaware. Just as Joe did, every night as a senator. He took the Amtrak train north so he could be home for his two young sons after the death of their mother and sister. What started in tragedy soon bonded him even further to our state and the people he represented, because no matter what, Joe was there. He always showed up when we needed him, just as he did for his sons.

As Delawareans, we've gotten used to an outsized influence because of Joe. From Wilmington to Dover to Georgetown, we've benefited from his presence in our lives. That will change this month when he leaves office and comes home. What won't change, however, is what he gave our state, and what our state gave him. I know I speak for many Delawareans when I say, thank you, Joe, for taking us to heights we've never reached before. Thank you, Joe, for being one of us, and showing the rest of America what it means to be a Delawarean.

Chris Coons is a U.S. senator from Delaware.

Dear President Biden,

I write this letter not as your constituent of nearly 50 years, nor as Delaware's former Secretary of Labor and Congresswoman, or our new United States Senator. Today, I write to you as a first-time grandmother on behalf of my beautiful granddaughter, Lennox. Lately, I've been reflecting on your presidency, and how I will describe your legacy to her. Three words immediately come to mind: progress, compassion and promise.

The first word is progress . You entered office amid a once-in-a-lifetime pandemic. At the time, our country had lost over 400,000 Americans to the COVID-19 pandemic. Unemployment was at 6%. We had to get our nation back on track - and you rose to the occasion. Working with Congress, you signed the American Rescue Plan Act into law to help us recover, rebuild, and restore. From life-saving vaccines to the reopening of our schools and businesses safely, your leadership in this turbulent time was consequential. We expanded the Child Tax Credit, which cut child poverty in half. We revived our economy.  As President, you ushered in an era of unprecedented legislative progress, while bringing our allies together, and I am proud to have worked alongside you in accomplishing these historic wins for Delaware and the nation.

History will show that working with Democrats and Republicans, you accomplished things that had only been talked about for decades. The historic Bipartisan Infrastructure Law is making transformational investments in our nation's roads, bridges, highways, ports, and rail, while expanding broadband internet to millions of Americans. By reaching across the aisle, you helped us keep our sacred obligation to our veterans by signing the Honoring Our PACT Act into law, which marked the largest expansion of VA benefits since the G.I. Bill. You fought for safer communities by signing into law the most comprehensive action ever taken to address gun violence, the Bipartisan Safer Communities Act . And working with Democrats in the House and Senate, you championed the Inflation Reduction Act to lower the cost of health care and prescription drug costs for seniors and make the largest investment in fighting the climate crisis in our nation's history. The impact your leadership will have on communities at home and abroad will undoubtedly be felt across generations. Simply put, you're leaving office as the most accomplished president in modern history.

The second word is compassion . When our country was at a crossroads after witnessing the horrific attack in Charlottesville, Virginia in 2017, and later the murder of George Floyd, you stepped up to bring back compassion at a time when our nation needed it most.

And for me, and countless others, you've been a compassionate friend and mentor. In 2014, when my husband suddenly and unexpectedly passed away; years later when my sister suffered a stroke; and most recently when my father, the late Ted Blunt, received the diagnosis of cancer and six months later left this earth - you were there. Even as I sought wisdom in my run for the Senate, you were there. It's a generosity that I hope you know is appreciated and will always be reciprocated. And despite tremendous personal loss throughout your own life, including the passing of your late son, Beau, you've continued to show us as individuals and as a country how to "keep the faith" in the face of adversity. That's because your North Star - your devotion to your state and nation - has never wavered.

The final word is promise . What you have brought with you from position to position has been a commitment to the promise of a better and brighter future for all Americans. The promise of a future where our schools, movie theaters, places of worship, and grocery stores are free from gun violence. The promise of a future where all Americans have access to quality and affordable health care, childcare, and housing opportunities. The promise of a future where our democracy is protected and not diminished. The promise of a future where access to clean drinking water isn't just a privilege but a basic human right. The promise of a nation where freedom, justice, and equality are the basis for everything we do. Thank you for all you've done to show us this future is achievable - if we're willing to work for it.

Mr. President, as you have often said, family is the beginning, middle, and the end so I would be remiss if I did not mention your other half, Dr. Jill Biden, and the unconditional love, strength, and support of your family. To the Bidens - thank you for being an anchor for the President and for sharing him with us.

Though my granddaughter is too young to read or write, she will grow up hearing of your decades of impactful service, your steadfast leadership, your deep compassion, your unwavering friendship, and your unshakeable optimism for the "possibilities" of America. The example you have set will inspire Lennox and future generations to lead with integrity, honor, and decency - not just in word but in deed. Thank you for your service to our state, our nation, and our future.

Sincerely,

U.S. Sen. Lisa Blunt Rochester

Lisa Blunt Rochester is one of Delaware's two U.S. senators, as well as the first Black Delawarean and the first woman to ever represent the First State in that chamber.

President Biden,

I'm honored to join thousands of our neighbors in thanking you for a lifetime of service to us, our state, and our country.

You are the definition of a true patriot, and you have led the most accomplished administration we've seen in my lifetime. Under your leadership, we have historic employment across the country, we've made critical investments in addressing climate change and we've bolstered economic opportunity for millions of Americans.

But I've been lucky to see you champion working families, and equity over my whole life - as my Senator, Vice President, and over the last three and a half years as President. In that time, you have proven that we can do big things together that make a real difference in the lives of Americans, from Wilmington to Scranton and beyond - and through it all, you have shown how decent, kind, and selfless you are.

Nearly 250 years ago, Delaware became the first state to sign on to the journey that is America. In the centuries since our small state has come to realize that the promise of our Constitution is only possible when we respect our differences and resolve our disagreements through conversation and collaboration. Through the power of our proximity here in this state, we have come to see our fellow citizens as neighbors with shared hopes and a common destiny. We know that the divisions and nastiness that we too often see nationally must not - and does not have to - be our new normal. That a different kind of politics is possible: a politics of hope, not of hate; of grace, not of grievance; of progress, not of pettiness.

This is the legacy you leave us with, as Delawareans and as Americans. It is a legacy that we are all called to honor especially now.

My heart is full of love for you, Jill, and the entire Biden family. Whenever I think of your legacy I am filled with love and adoration for Beau - who taught me that there is no better quality in a public servant than authenticity. Beau was always the same sweet, kind, and generous man behind closed doors as he was in front of a crowd. I count myself lucky to have gotten to know you through the eyes of your son, Beau.

When I won my race for Congress this fall, you called me to say that you got a message from heaven from Beau: "Beau's looking down from heaven, congratulating you." I'll always remember that call from you. Mr. President, I know that today and every day Beau is proud of you.

At this moment in America's journey, hope sometimes feels hard to come by, your legacy reminds us that we must never forget that we are the beneficiaries of seemingly impossible change becoming a reality; that it's always been in our country's most significant challenges that we take our biggest steps forward. Because no matter what obstacles stand in our way, so long as we breathe, we hope - and, together, we can once again turn that hope into historic progress.

It's easy to be cynical but you, Mr. President, have never done that - you have shown us that in facing the most impossible of circumstances, we always have the propensity to take our biggest steps forward. Now more than ever, we need to channel that hope and determination to build on the work you have accomplished.

Mr. President, yes, you showed me how to be a good public servant and how to serve our state with integrity, grit, and decency. More than that, you showed me how to summon courage and hope after tremendous personal loss. That is a gift that I will always treasure.

It's only fitting that I'm writing this letter on the Amtrak. Mr. President, welcome home. You will always be my idol.

Sincerely,

Congresswoman Sarah McBride

Rep. Sarah McBride is Delaware's sole congresswoman beginning this year, as well as the first openly transgender politician ever elected to those halls.

Dear Mr. President,

A simple truth: YOU ARE THE BEST. Mr. President, Joseph R. Biden, Jr., you are the best person, president, and public servant I have ever had the great good fortune of knowing and serving. So many people can and will say the same. So, let me be more specific about the difference you have made in my life and have enabled me to make in the lives of others, thanks to the trust you placed in me.

Serving as U.S. Ambassador to Germany and representing you and your Administration overseas has been the greatest honor of my life. I could not be prouder of the work we have done to defend democracy and to advance all our shared values and interests with Germany.  Germany is now a stronger partner than ever with the U.S, thanks to your global leadership.

I know the important role your father played in your life, and I could not be more grateful to you for enabling me to pay the greatest possible tribute to my father. As the daughter of Kurt Gutmann, who fled Nazi Germany in 1934, I could never have imagined that I would go on to serve as your envoy to his home country one generation later.

That day I received your unexpected call informing me of your intention to nominate me as Ambassador, I felt so many emotions, but the one that has stuck with me most is gratitude. I am grateful to call you a friend and to have had the privilege and pleasure of getting to know you over the past twenty years. I am deeply grateful for your public service over half a century and for the unsurpassed good that you have accomplished in your Presidency for the nation, and the world.

When we first discussed the idea of your joining the University of Pennsylvania after your Vice Presidency, I could not have imagined in that moment that you would go on to run for President again. When you decided not to run in 2015 after the passing of your beloved Beau, you were so focused on all that you would go on to do after leaving office.  Among so many other things, you launched the Cancer Moonshot initiative, and your focus was inspiring young people. You certainly did that, and I literally was by your side in observing how much you taught-and inspired-our students. You brought such a depth and richness of experience, insight, and wisdom to our campus in that time.

It has always been important for universities to bring leaders from across the political spectrum to engage with students, and you engaged with your unsurpassed and irresistible passion. Penn students benefited enormously from your unique vision. Everyone loves to talk about their memorable interactions with you as Professor Biden. What I said at the time bears repeating because it shows what an amazing and unique President you are:

Every time Joe Biden...visited campus, he brought forth endless expertise on a wide variety of topics-from international affairs and domestic politics to immigration policy and cancer research, and so much more... His unmatched personal connections with global leaders made our mission to bring the world to Penn and Penn to the world even stronger.

I saw firsthand how valuable these personal relationships are to diplomacy, from Oval Office meetings with Chancellor Scholz, to your recent October visit to Berlin where President Steinmeier presented you with the Order of Merit at the highest level- Germany's highest tribute - for your commitment to the transatlantic alliance since your days in the Senate.

Years before I had ever attended a Munich Security Conference (MSC), you shared your passion for this global convening with me - a forum that embodies how meaningful effective person-to-person diplomacy can be. The beginning of my Ambassadorship was marked by rushing to attend my first MSC just days before Russia's unprovoked, brutal reinvasion of Ukraine. We lost no time in urging Germany and our other allies to be prepared to stand with us in supporting Ukraine. It was not lost on me how serious our work was and continues to be. Your leadership made it possible for Ukraine to resist Putin's aggression.

Over the years, we have discussed our shared passions for democracy and education, collaborative medical research, and creating job opportunities for the middle class. You always took a keen interest in my perspective, as a scholar of democracy and as the first person in my family to attend college. When I was Chair of President Obama's Commission on the Study of Bioethical Issues, I saw your integrity and commitment to improving the lives of Americans firsthand. There is no greater honor and privilege that I could have imagined in my life than to work with you, and now call you a friend. I have learned so much from your principled leadership, decency, and vision. Thank you for this. Thank you for being the best - and a mensch!

With gratitude,

Amy Gutmann

Amy Gutmann is the Christopher H. Browne Distinguished Professor of Political Science, School of Arts and Sciences, and professor of communication at the Annenberg School for Communication. She is also a Penn president emerita and a retired U.S. ambassador to Germany.

For more than three years, I've been fortunate to serve as chairman of President Joe Biden's Board of Advisors on Historically Black Colleges and Universities.

After much reflection, I am resigning that position on Monday, full of gratitude for President Biden's tremendous record of service, and proud of what we've accomplished together.

Here's the truth: no president in U.S. history has done more to support HBCUs than Joe Biden.

While many have suggested they understand the importance of America's HBCUs, the Biden/Harris administration's actions can be summed up this way:

"Deeds; not words."

Since their election in 2020, Biden and Vice President Kamala Harris have invested $20 billion in our country's HBCUs.

That includes nearly $4 billion through the American Rescue Plan and other COVID relief legislation to help HBCUs support students' ability to meet basic needs and maintain campus operations; $2.6 billion from the U.S. Department of Education to support the growth and sustainability of HBCU degree programs; more than $1.6 billion through federal grants, cooperative agreements, and other competitive funding opportunities to drive academic and training programs; and almost $950 million to support HBCUs in growing research capacity and infrastructure.

Biden and Harris made these investments because they understand the unmistakable value of America's HBCUs.

Across the country - despite representing only a small fraction of higher education institutions - HBCUs educate twice as many students who are low-income and Pell eligible as non-HBCUs.

And they do so with incredible success.

In addition to generating nearly $16 billion in direct economic impact, HBCUs still produce 80% of Black judges, 25% of Black science professionals, 70% of Black dentists and physicians, and 40% of Black members of Congress. And the return-on-investment for HBCUs is not just financial. On every indicator of well-being, Black students attending HBCUs students fare better than similarly situated students at Predominantly White Institutions, or PWIs.

Biden's decisions to invest in America's HBCUs will have a significant impact on generations of students who attend these institutions, the faculty and staff who pour their whole hearts into providing HBCU educations, and the families who sacrifice so much in favor of boundless futures for their children.

We know Joe Biden in Delaware. So we're not surprised by his commitment to service. But his work as president has been singular in its commitment, and will be forever remembered by a grateful set of American citizens who will continue to achieve in every field of human endeavor.

"Deeds; not words."

In four years, Biden's deeds are unprecedented: tangible artifacts - demonstrable symbols - of an incomparable legacy.

Tony Allen is president of Delaware State University and chairman emeritus of the President's Board of Advisors on Historically Black Colleges and Universities.

Joe Biden's Delaware: Our guide to the 46th's president's important places, sites

Before Joe Biden headed to take his place at the White House in 2021, he told a send-off crowd, "When I die, Delaware will be written on my heart."

But Biden's name is already written across Delaware, on pools and rest stops, while his mere presence put other places on the map. Biden has forever changed Delaware's place in history - and the places in Delaware history.

This is a map of Joe Biden's Delaware.

Greenville home, 1209 Barley Mill Road : The Bidens call their Barley Mill Road home "the Lake House," though the body of water next to it is a manmade pond. They've lived there since 1998. Joe Biden, an architecture enthusiast, designed the 7,000-square-foot home himself.

North Shores home, 34 Farview Road, Rehoboth Beach : The Bidens bought a home in the community just north of Rehoboth Beach in 2017, but they had been spending time in Rehoboth Beach for decades prior. While Joe Biden used to be seen around town with an ice cream cone in hand, nowadays, few-and-far-between outings include the Secret Service.

St. Joseph on the Brandywine Roman Catholic Church , 10 Old Church Road, Greenville: "St. Joe's" is the home church of Joe Biden, only the second Catholic U.S. president in history. Neilia, Naomi and Beau Biden are buried in the church's cemetery.

St. Edmond's Roman Catholic Church , 409 King Charles Ave., Rehoboth Beach: This is where Joe Biden attends Mass when he's in "The Nation's Summer Capital."

Archmere Academy , 3600 Philadelphia Pike, Claymont: Joe Biden played football and was senior class president at this private Catholic high school in Claymont. His sons, Beau and Hunter, attended Archmere as well.

University of Delaware , 17 W. Main St., Newark: Joe Biden majored in political science and history at the Newark college, graduating in 1965.

Joseph R. Biden Jr. Aquatic Center , 26th and Locust streets, Wilmington: A city pool in Prices Run where Joe lifeguarded in the summer of 1962. Out of 12 lifeguards that summer, he was the only one who wasn't Black. The well-known story of him taking on "Corn Pop" is set at this pool, which was renamed for him in 2017.

Claymont: Joe Biden's family moved from Scranton, Pennsylvania, to Claymont when he was about 10 years old, making a home at Brookview Apartments while Joe attended Holy Rosary. Two years later, the family moved to the new Brandywine Hundred housing development of Mayfield and Joe started school at St. Helena's. Later, he attended Claymont's Archmere Academy.

Hotel du Pont , 42 W. 11th St., Wilmington: The iconic Wilmington hotel where Joe Biden held his first-ever Senate campaign kickoff party, and later a victory celebration.

Neilia Hunter Biden Park, 309 S. Woodward Ave., near Elsmere: New Castle County named this park in honor of Joe Biden's late wife.

Joseph R. Biden Jr. Railroad Station , 100 French St., Wilmington: After the death of Neilia and Naomi Biden, Joe Biden took the train back and forth between Washington and Wilmington to spend more time with his sons. He spent so much time on the train he was nicknamed "Amtrak Joe," and the Wilmington Amtrak station was renamed for him in 2008.

Return Day , The Circle, Georgetown: The uniquely Sussex County celebration based on the historic practice of "returning" to the county seat two days after an election to hear the results. Traditionally, the winning politicians ride in carriages with their opponents in a parade. Joe Biden rode in the parade many times over the years, including in 2008, when he was elected vice president.

Dover Air Force Base , Dover: This military base's mortuary handles the remains of most servicemembers killed overseas. Joe Biden has attended many "dignified transfers" there, solemnly observing as a deceased servicemember returns to the U.S.

Piane Grill , 913 N. Market St., Wilmington: The now-closed Piane's is where Joe and Neilia Biden and family celebrated his birthday after his 1972 Senate win, and shortly before the car accident that claimed Neilia's and daughter Naomi Biden's lives.

Ristorante Attilio , 1900 Lancaster Ave., Wilmington: A favorite restaurant of Joe and Jill Biden's and where they ate - and received a standing ovation - after Joe's failed 1987 presidential run.

Mrs. Robino's Restaurant , 520 W. Union St., Wilmington: Joe Biden last ate at this landmark Italian restaurant in February 2024 with his sister, Valerie Biden Owens.

Charcoal Pit , 2600 Concord Pike, Talleyville: Joe Biden is a longtime fan of the Wilmington burger joint. Thanks to him, in 2016, President Barack Obama stopped in to chat with patrons, and at the 2024 Democratic National Convention, someone brought him and Vice President Kamala Harris two Charcoal Pit milkshakes. A delighted Joe explained he'd been drinking their triple-thick black-and-white milkshakes since high school.

Widener School of Law , 4601 Concord Pike, Talleyville: Now called Widener University Delaware Law School, starting in 1991, Joe Biden taught constitutional law at this institution for 17 years.

Cape Henlopen State Park: The Lewes-area state park where the Delaware Bay meets the Atlantic Ocean backs up to the Bidens' North Shores home. Joe Biden often cycles the park's Gordons Pond trail, and at Herring Point, there's a bench bearing late son Beau Biden's name.

Biden Welcome Center , 520 JFK Memorial Highway, near Newark: The Delaware rest stop on I-95 named for the former vice president in 2018.
